4. New England
--------------

**Best for forest drives and exploring charming centuries-old towns**

Want to meander on mountain roads beneath brilliant forest canopies and savor tasty lobster and coastal views all in the same trip?[New England](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/usa/new-england), the cluster of six states at the USA’s northeast corner,is the place for you. Explore the quaint villages, cranberry bogs and golden beaches of [Cape Cod](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/usa/cape-cod);snuggle into a cabin in[Vermont](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/usa/new-england/vermont); tackle the mountains of [New Hampshire](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/articles/guide-to-new-hampshire); or dive into all the seafood you can eat in [Portland](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/articles/guide-to-portland-maine), [Maine](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/usa/new-england/maine). And if you visit in autumn, prepare yourself for some of [the most spectacular fall foliage in the country](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/articles/best-fall-colors-us).

5. New Orleans, Louisiana
-------------------------

**Best for foodies and art lovers**

There’s no place in the world like [New Orleans](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/usa/new-orleans) – we promise. A vibrant cocktail of Indigenous, Caribbean, African, French and Spanish influences, [this city possesses a unique magic](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/articles/top-things-to-do-in-new-orleans) that keeps people returning again and again. Dive into its legendary Creole cuisine, revel in its lively festivals and immerse yourself in a world-class music scene – this is the birthplace of jazz, after all.

Eat a beignet heaped with powdered sugar and drink a cup of chicory coffee at [Cafe du Monde](https://shop.cafedumonde.com/), which overlooks [Jackson Square](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/usa/new-orleans/french-quarter/attractions/jackson-square/a/poi-sig/381165/1329657) and [St Louis Cathedral](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/usa/new-orleans/french-quarter/attractions/st-louis-cathedral/a/poi-sig/381293/1329657). Then take a tour of the famously atmospheric streets of the French Quarter.

Be sure to get beyond the Quarter, too. Explore the antique stores of Magazine St, take in the mansions and cemeteries of the [Garden District](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/articles/garden-district-new-orleans-guide), play a round of golf in[Audubon Park](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/usa/new-orleans/uptown-and-riverbend/attractions/audubon-park/a/poi-sig/1512150/1329661), or even [get out into nearby bayous](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/articles/best-day-trips-new-orleans) on an airboat tour.

6. The Everglades, Florida
--------------------------

**Best for wildlife watchers**

It’s hard to overstate the importance of [the Everglades](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/usa/florida/the-everglades).This sprawling wetland ecosystem is home to a diverse profusion of flora and fauna, which has earned it a designation as an International Biosphere Reserve, a [UNESCO World Heritage Site](https://whc.unesco.org/en/list/76/)and a [US national park](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/usa/florida/the-everglades/attractions/everglades-national-park/a/poi-sig/1366106/361921). You can take in the endless stretches of grass and bayous by slowly paddling through coastal estuaries in a kayak or whizzing through the numerous waterways via airboat. Camping overnight among the mangroves offers an even deeper connection to the place. All the while, keep your eyes peeled for wading birds, manatees, and (of course) alligators and crocodiles.

**Planning tip:** For the best experience, come prepared for the elements. Sunscreen and bug spray are essentials.

7. Pacific Coast Highway
------------------------

**Best for West Coast exploration**

The Pacific Coast Highway connects sunny [San Diego](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/usa/san-diego) with moody [Seattle](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/usa/seattle), delivering epic West Coast experiences along its 1600-mile length. (Technically, it’s three separate but continuous highways.) Along the way, you can stay at kitschy motels in coastal towns, admire the cliffs of [Big Sur](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/usa/california/big-sur), marvel at the tide pools in [Oregon](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/usa/pacific-northwest/oregon)and explore [Washington](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/usa/pacific-northwest/washington)’s[Olympic National Park](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/usa/pacific-northwest/olympic-national-park).

One small California town, San Simeon, is especially worth a stop.The oceanfront[Piedras Blancas Rookery](https://visitsansimeonca.com/what-to-do/elephant-seals-san-simeon/)is the only elephant-seal rookery in the world that’s only easily accessible and free. The dozens of seals lounging in the sun and barking along the beach and rocks make for quite a spectacle.

Just up the road is the fabled[Hearst Castle,](https://hearstcastle.org/) the former home of newspaper magnate William Randolph Hearst – and a monument to one man’s over-the-top vision. It features a wild blend of architectural styles and details that take inspiration from everything from ancient Rome to the Renaissance, with orange groves and palms imported from the Canary Islands flanking the cathedral-like home.

**Planning tip:**Sections of the PCH follow sea cliffs prone to rockslides. Always check road conditions before setting off in case of any unexpected closures.

8. Washington, DC
-----------------

**Best for national history**

[Washington, DC](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/usa/washington-dc)’s [National Mall](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/articles/guide-to-national-mall-washington-dc)embodies the ideals of American political life. Along this 2-mile strip – with the [US Capitol](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/usa/washington-dc/capitol-hill-south-dc/attractions/us-capitol/a/poi-sig/385385/1329650)at one end and the[Lincoln Memorial](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/usa/washington-dc/national-mall/attractions/lincoln-memorial/a/poi-sig/385369/1329647)at the other – the USA’s cultural history is captured through iconic monuments and some the country’s most famous museums. The mall contains 10 Smithsonian institutions – the [National Museum of Natural History](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/usa/washington-dc/national-mall/attractions/national-museum-of-natural-history/a/poi-sig/1097056/1329647), the [National Museum of African American History and Culture](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/usa/washington-dc/national-mall/attractions/national-museum-of-african-american-history-culture/a/poi-sig/1246939/1329647) and the [National Museum of American History,](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/usa/washington-dc/national-mall/attractions/national-museum-of-american-history/a/poi-sig/1097060/1329647) among others – plus others including the [National Gallery of Art](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/usa/washington-dc/national-mall/attractions/national-gallery-of-art/a/poi-sig/385373/1329647). The [Washington Monument](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/usa/washington-dc/national-mall/attractions/washington-monument/a/poi-sig/385389/1329647) rises at the center of the Mall – reaching as high as the country’s ideals.

9. Santa Fe, New Mexico
-----------------------

**Best for Indigenous history and culture**

You can’t escape the centuries of history in[Santa Fe](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/usa/santa-fe) – yet this one-of-a-kind city always manages to keep up with the times. A cultural melange of Indigenous, Spanish and Mexican influences, this [New Mexican](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/usa/southwest/new-mexico) capital is home to numerous historical sites, including its 400-year-old [Plaza](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/usa/santa-fe/attractions/the-plaza/a/poi-sig/1347720/362156)and the [Loretto Chapel](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/usa/santa-fe/attractions/loretto-chapel/a/poi-sig/414044/362156)(with its famous staircase).

The city is also famously creative: the surrounding desert landscapes provided endless inspiration to [Georgia O’Keeffe](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/usa/santa-fe/attractions/georgia-o-keeffe-museum/a/poi-sig/414032/362156), while upscale galleries along Canyon Rd are filled with works from contemporary artists. And then there’s[Meow Wolf](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/usa/santa-fe/attractions/meow-wolf/a/poi-sig/1558571/362156), the game-changing, genre-defying immersive art installation that has to be visited to be believed.

**Detour:**Less than an hour's drive from Santa Fe, the [Puyé Cliff Dwellings](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/usa/new-mexico/northern-pueblos/attractions/puye-cliff-dwellings/a/poi-sig/1254453/1341886), carved into the rock face and atop the Santa Clara Canyon on Santa Clara Pueblo Reservation, were once home to 1500 Pueblo Indians. The site was abandoned in 1580; today, one-hour tours are conducted by the descendants of the original dwellers.

10. San Francisco, California
-----------------------------

**Best for counterculture**

[San Francisco](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/usa/san-francisco) combines the energy of a major city with a distinctly laid-back and gracious West Coast energy. Take in breathtaking bay views at [Golden Gate Park](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/usa/san-francisco/golden-gate-park-and-the-avenues/attractions/golden-gate-park/a/poi-sig/383395/1329646), wander the alleyways of the country’s largest and oldest [Chinese neighborhood](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/usa/san-francisco/north-beach-and-chinatown), pay homage to LGBTIQ+ heroes in the Castro, or dive into cutting-edge art at [SFMOMA](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/usa/san-francisco/downtown-and-civic-center/attractions/san-francisco-museum-of-modern-art/a/poi-sig/383419/1329640) and a plethora of local galleries. This place contains multitudes.

11. Key West, Florida
---------------------

**Best for sunshine, seafood and free-spirited living**

[Key West](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/usa/florida/key-west)’s famous quirkiness never fails to delight. You’ll feel the vibes every evening at[Mallory Square](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/usa/florida/key-west/attractions/mallory-square/a/poi-sig/453229/361914), when the daily sunset street fair combines food, eclectic performers and artists selling their wares. On a stroll through side streets, you can take in historic homes framed by palms and bougainvillea; be sure to visit the [Ernest Hemingway House](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/usa/florida/key-west/attractions/hemingway-house/a/poi-sig/1186639/361914).

**Planning tip:**There’s no better way to get around Key West than by foot. To help navigate the town, download a [map](https://www.cityofkeywest-fl.gov/9/Visitors), or stop by the city’s tourism office at 1300 White St.

12. Rocky Mountains, Colorado
-----------------------------

**Best for big peaks and winter sports**

The the Rockies in [Colorado](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/usa/rocky-mountains/colorado) are simply astonishing – and even more beautiful than you’ve heard. There are many ways to take them: with a hike in[Rocky Mountains National Park](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/usa/colorado/northern-colorado/attractions/rocky-mountain-national-park/a/poi-sig/1578014/1326457); by hitting the slopes in ski hubs like [Vail](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/usa/rocky-mountains/vail), [Aspen](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/usa/rocky-mountains/aspen) and Telluride; on a drive along the scenic byways of the San Juan range; or by camping in one of the state’s numerous national forests. Nature’s grandeur awaits.

**Planning tip:** Unless you’re from somewhere with similar elevation, you might feel the effects of altitude throughout the Rockies; stay extremely hydrated, take your time on hikes and skip the alcohol.

13. Chicago, Illinois
---------------------

**Best metropolis for Midwestern charm**

[Chicago](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/usa/chicago) contains all the hallmarks of a great American city: [excellent food](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/articles/what-to-eat-and-drink-in-chicago), [multicultural neighborhoods](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/articles/best-neighborhoods-in-chicago)and top-tier museums – yet with a vibe that’s both unmistakably Midwestern and unique in the world.

Leave your car behind and explore[Millennium Park](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/usa/chicago/the-loop/attractions/millennium-park/a/poi-sig/378727/1319210), the lakefront and the museum campus by[Segway](https://chicagosegways.com/). Board a[boat](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/articles/chicago-3-day-itinerary)for a narrated tour of the architectural wonders lining the Chicago River (the skyscraper was invented here, after all). From the boat docks, head north for a stroll along the[Magnificent Mile](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/usa/chicago/near-north-and-navy-pier/attractions/magnificent-mile/a/poi-sig/1247048/1319211), the stretch of Michigan Ave that’s lined with boutiques, art galleries, restaurants and the historic[Water Tower](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/usa/chicago/gold-coast/attractions/water-tower/a/poi-sig/378763/1319209), one of the few survivors of the disastrous Chicago Fire of 1871.

Have more time? Spend sunny days on a city beach on the ocean-size Lake Michigan, catch a Cubs game at [Wrigley Field](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/usa/chicago/lake-view-and-wrigleyville/attractions/wrigley-field/a/poi-sig/1131189/1319212), or have an evening of laughs at Second City, the launchpad for greats like Stephen Colbert and Tina Fey.

14. Charleston, South Carolina
------------------------------

**Best for Southern charm**

Live oaks dripping with Spanish moss, historic mansions and cobblestone streets make [Charleston](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/usa/the-south/charleston) a must on any USA bucket list. From carriage rides to kayaks to bikes, this city is fetching no matter[how you explore it](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/articles/getting-around-charleston).Civil War buffs should hop on a ferry to visit [historic Fort Sumter](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/usa/the-south/charleston/attractions/guardians-of-charleston-harbor/a/poi-sig/1250743/362220); anyone will enjoy a stroll along [The Battery](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/usa/south-carolina/charleston/south-of-broad-the-french-quarter/attractions/battery-white-point-garden/a/poi-sig/456593/1342222), the former defensive walls along the waterfront that today form a wonderful city promenade and park.

**Planning tip:** The [best time to visit Charleston](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/articles/best-times-to-visit-charleston) is fall, when the humidity drops; and during the holidays, as the city positively glitters with decorations.

The 8 best under-the-radar places to visit in the Caribbean
===========================================================

There are no secret Caribbean resorts, but there are places where you can get away from it all © fokkebok / Getty Images

Few places compare to [the Caribbean](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/caribbean) when it comes to sun, sea, sand and surf.

The bluest of blues and turquoise waters make for some of [the world’s best beaches](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/articles/best-beaches-caribbean). It is paradise. No hurries, no worries, just relax – it’s no wonder around 30 million people a year head to the Caribbean for a respite.

While the [Dominican Republic](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/dominican-republic), [Jamaica](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/jamaica), [Puerto Rico](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/puerto-rico), and [the Bahamas](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/the-bahamas) are hot spots, the Caribbean is also home to locales without hordes of tourists and some where there is more wildlife than people. So, if you’re in the mood for the beauty without the bustle, here’s where to go.

1. Kamalame Cay, the Bahamas
----------------------------

**Best for a luxurious private island getaway**

 Advertisement 

Some things are worth waiting for. Get to [Nassau](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/the-bahamas/new-providence/nassau), hop on a commuter flight, take a cab to the dock and board a water taxi that takes you to[Kamalame Cay,](https://www.kamalame.com/) a private island in Andros in [the Bahamas](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/the-bahamas/). The resort is near the world’s third-largest barrier reef with acres of coconut palm groves and vegetation that competes with the bluest sea for what is most awesome.

If you want an island escape, this might just be it. The bungalows, villas, cottages, and beach houses are spread out for miles. Wheel around in your golf cart on white sand roads and it’s mostly you and Mother Nature with just enough people to have a little atmosphere. Activities include everything from deep-sea fishing and kayaking to playing tennis and cycling. If you’re in chill mode, watch a movie at the alfresco cinema, climb in a hammock along the beach or head to the Bahamas’ only overwater spa. You’re also in good hands at the Great House restaurant, where the conch fritters, Asian barbecue spareribs, and the coconut green vegetable curry are crowd-pleasers.

Make sure you venture back to Andros, with its underwater cave systems and the highest concentration of blue holes in the world. One of the most popular is Captain Bill’s Blue Hole in [Blue Holes National Park](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/the-bahamas/north-central-andros/attractions/blue-holes-national-park/a/poi-sig/1555378/1332437). After a short drive, make your way through the pine forest, get up your nerve and jump from the platform into the fresh water. For a quieter experience, head to the [Androsia Batik Factory](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/the-bahamas/north-central-andros/attractions/androsia-ltd/a/poi-sig/1393989/1332437) where you can learn about the art of batik-making and try your hand at it.

![Image 25: A lush green coastline with a small village of houses](https://lp-cms-production.imgix.net/2022-12/Jamaica-iStock-1000710180-RFC.jpeg?auto=format,compress&q=72&fit=crop)

Bluefields is a chilled out spot on Jamaica's south coast © dimarik / Getty Images

2. Bluefields, Jamaica
----------------------

**Best for solitude**

When you think Jamaica, [Montego Bay](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/jamaica/montego-bay) and [Negril](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/jamaica/negril-and-the-west/negril) probably come to mind. Skip the masses and head to Bluefields on the south coast instead. You can still arrange dive tours, deep-sea fishing, glass-bottom boat cruises but along this hilly stretch of coast, you’re more likely to hear the cicadas’ concert than anything loud and late.

While you’re in the area, take a tour of the [Bluefields Organic Fruit Farm](https://www.facebook.com/bluefieldsorganicfruitfarmtours/?ref=br_rs) where you'll learn a bit about organic farming and Jamaican agricultural history. Decide which island treats – perhaps coconuts, pineapples, naseberries, avocados, gineps, star apples or garden cherries – you want to take back to your hotel or the beach to enjoy.

Also nearby in Belmont Falls in a small yard off the main road is the monument that pays tribute to reggae legend Peter Tosh who spent his early years there. Tosh, one of the original Wailers, in reggae music history is not far behind icon Bob Marley. For an authentic Jamaican experience, mix it up with locals at [Bluefields Beach Park](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/jamaica/bluefields-belmont/attractions/bluefields-beach-park/a/poi-sig/1424487/1332805) where, at the weekends, families will be picnicking and the reggae music will be blasting.

**Planning tip:** If after all that peace and solitude you want to liven things up a little, Negril is an hour away. Here you'll find hipster haunts like Rick’s Café where you can dance and watch folks jump from cliffs into the sea.

3. South Caicos, Turks and Caicos
---------------------------------

**Best for finding your zen**

 Advertisement 

[Providenciales](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/turks-and-caicos/caicos-islands/providenciales) gets all the glory, but [South Caicos](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/turks-and-caicos) is a Caribbean gem worth your time. Fly into Providenciales and take a 30-minute flight to South Caicos. Location is everything. Don’t look for bars and mega resorts, but wild donkeys and salt flats with pink flamingos.

Let nature soothe your soul. There are two beaches here with possible dolphin- and humpback whale-sightings. Visit Iguana Island and the aquarium, a protected reef ideal for snorkeling, and get a glimpse of local life in old town Cockburn. For fun and fantastic food, make your way to Triple J’s, a backyard barbecue restaurant only open on the weekends. It's a friendly spot where the music is pumping. Fill up on jerk pork, chicken, ribs, grilled lobster, fish and conch, and of course peas and rice.

Take an excursion to Long Cay, part of the Admiral Cockburn Land and Sea National Park, a protected area full of ospreys, egrets, herons and more. Long Cay is also where you’ll find tons of Rock Iguanas. South Caicos is typically pretty windy and there are many flat water and bay kiting locations, so kiteboarders will have plenty of reasons to be psyched.

**Planning tip:** Consider spending a day in Providenciales. There are new hot spots like the [BLT Steakhouse](https://www.ritzcarlton.com/en/hotels/caribbean/turks-and-caicos/dining) at the Ritz-Carlton and the uber-luxe [MRVL Spa](https://www.mrvlspa.com/) for next-level pampering.

![Image 26: Scuba divers in full gear head down stairs towards a beach for a shore dive](https://lp-cms-production.imgix.net/2022-12/Bonaire-iStock-1170310192-RFE.jpeg?auto=format,compress&q=72&fit=crop)

Bonaire has nearly 90 dive sites to experience © Orietta Gaspari / Getty Images

4. Bonaire
----------

**Best for diving**

[Bonaire](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/aruba-bonaire-and-curacao/bonaire), one of the ABC islands ([Aruba](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/aruba-bonaire-and-curacao/aruba), Bonaire and [Curaçao](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/aruba-bonaire-and-curacao/curacao)), doesn’t get the buzz of the other two. But divers know this part of the Dutch Caribbean is where the action is, with nearly 90 dive sites, coral reefs, and sea caves. Iguanas, parrots, and other critters call Bonaire home, and [Gotomeer](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/aruba-bonaire-and-curacao/bonaire/north-of-kralendijk/attractions/gotomeer/a/poi-sig/1549190/1330986) is a saltwater lagoon on the island’s northern end where you’ll see flamingos.

There’s fun to be had at [Washington-Slagbaai National Park](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/aruba-bonaire-and-curacao/bonaire/north-of-kralendijk/attractions/washington-slagbaai-national-park/a/poi-sig/365861/1330986), be it hiking to the tallest peak at Mt Brandaris, cliff-jumping into turquoise waters at Boka Slagbaii or chilling in the tide pool at Boka Kokolishi. Windsurf and kayak through mangroves. For a unique golfing experience, play on Bonaire’s natural golf desert course (where wild goats and donkeys roam). When hunger calls, you can find everything from a food truck on the beach to fine dining in Sebastian’s.

5. Nevis, St Kitts and Nevis
----------------------------

**Best for hikers**

[Nevis](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/st-kitts-and-nevis/nevis), in the Leeward Islands, is one of the Caribbean’s best kept secrets. The smaller of the dual-island nation of [St Kitts and Nevis](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/st-kitts-and-nevis), its mystique is the inactive volcano, mountains, often shrouded in mist, and the Nevis Peak at more than 975m (3200ft). The beaches are beautiful and uncrowded where wild donkeys, goats, and green vervet monkeys roam. Take an adventurous climb up Mt Nevis or a less intense hike to rainforest waterfalls.

Don’t miss [the Botanical Gardens of Nevis](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/st-kitts-nevis/south-nevis/attractions/botanical-gardens-of-nevis/a/poi-sig/1055861/1005470), home to tropical plants from around the world and stunning artwork. The [Nevis Equestrian Centre](https://www.nevishorseback.com/) offers rides that include beaches, trails, and villages. The fishing is good in these parts too, where barracuda, sailfish, and blue marlin are plentiful.

Dine at The Rocks that sits 300m (1000ft) above sea level on the grounds of the [Golden Rock Inn](https://www.goldenrocknevis.com/), where you can enjoy magnificent sea views, cascading ponds, and lush gardens. For a history lesson, there’s Hamilton House, the Georgian style building in Charlestown where Alexander Hamilton was born and raised, now the [Museum of Nevis History](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/st-kitts-and-nevis/nevis/charlestown/attractions/museum-of-nevis-history/a/poi-sig/1396674/358150).

Consider staying at the [Four Seasons Resort](https://www.fourseasons.com/nevis/) on Pinney’s Beach. Sit seaside, nestled by rocks watching the sunset at the resort’s Mango restaurant. Another good choice is [The Hermitage](https://hermitagenevis.com/) at the foot of a rainforest covered mountain.

**Planning tip:**Spend a day on the sister island of St Kitts where you can hike Mt Liamuiga Volcano and check out [Brimstone Hill Fortress National Park](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/st-kitts-nevis/northern-st-kitts/attractions/brimstone-hill-fortress-national-park/a/poi-sig/1396637/1331211).

![Image 27: A woman stands on a board walk that cuts through a dense rainforest landscape](https://lp-cms-production.imgix.net/2022-12/Dominica-iStock-82068128-RFC.jpeg?auto=format,compress&q=72&fit=crop)

Hire a guide to get the best out of your time in Dominica © David Madison / Getty Images

6. Dominica
-----------

**Best for nature lovers**

Not to be confused with the Dominican Republic, [Dominica](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/dominica) is one of the most unique Caribbean islands. Nicknamed “The nature island of the Caribbean”, the thrills are loggerhead turtles, whales, hot springs, boiling lakes, mountains, waterfalls, and black sand beaches.

[Morne Trois Pitons National Park](https://whc.unesco.org/en/list/814/) is a national treasure with spots like [Trafalgar Falls](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/dominica/trafalgar-falls/attractions/trafalgar-falls/a/poi-sig/1020530/358046). Morne Trois Pitons is an active volcano, one of nine in Dominica. Trek the park’s trails with views of mountains and the rainforest. Kayak and snorkel in [Soufriere-Scott’s Head Marine Reserve](https://whc.unesco.org/en/tentativelists/6022/). For a wellness themed retreat there’s [Jungle Bay](https://www.junglebaydominica.com/caribbean-islands-packages?gclid=Cj0KCQiAyracBhDoARIsACGFcS63KJ_Yna0bdZYytZ9EtH2nBJCEU4ycyY5c1Q4l0_BsxaH9YJ2rqfcaArRREALw_wcB) on nearly 20 acres of lush landscape. Revitalize yourself at the Bamboo Spa with the signature Jungle Bay Massage with coconut, castor and bay essential oils.

**Planning tip:** Have the concierge hook you up with a local guide. Dominica has many nooks and crannies you might not discover on your own.

7. Tobago
---------

**Best for bird-watchers**

[Trinidad](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/trinidad-and-tobago/trinidad) is beloved for its iconic carnival, but sister island [Tobago](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/trinidad-and-tobago/tobago) is often overlooked. This less-traveled paradise is a must for bird-watchers. Tobago has one of the highest densities of bird species in the world, with more than 200 varieties. Tobago’s Unesco World Heritage Site, [Main Ridge Forest Reserve](https://whc.unesco.org/en/tentativelists/5646/) is the oldest protected forest in the western hemisphere, with nine trails to keep hikers happy.

You'll hear great music in the birthplace of the steel pan drum. Soak up the sounds on a Sunday night at the legendary street party, [Buccoo Sunday School](http://www.buccoo.net/treasures/buccoo-sunday-school) in Buccoo. Those with a sweet tooth might want to book a tour of the [Tobago Cocoa Estate](https://www.tobagococoa.com/). The island's best beaches include Buccoo Bay and Englishman’s Bay, or cool off with a bold jump into Argyle Falls, Tobago’s highest waterfall.

8. Canouan, St Vincent and the Grenadines
-----------------------------------------

**Best for turtle lovers**

Here, tortoises outnumber people. What you will find plenty of on this 3.5-mile island in [St Vincent and the Grenadines](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/st-vincent-and-the-grenadines), is boats, incredible ones at the [Sandy Lane Yacht Club](https://slycr.com/berthing/). Canouan has bragging rights for being surrounded by the Caribbean’s largest living coral reef and there’s good fly-fishing and kitesurfing here too. Check into the [Mandarin Oriental, Canouan](https://www.mandarinoriental.com/en/canouan/caribbean) and you may feel like you’re in a private-island sanctuary, a secret escape, with just 26 suites and 13 villas on the 1200-acre estate that’s on Godahl Beach. Spend time on the 18-hole golf course or relaxing in the spa. Snorkeling in lagoons and hiking up Mt. Royal make for more fun.

**Planning tip:** The Mandarin has a six-seat resort jet that can be booked as a shared or private charter from Barbados, St Lucia, Grenada, Martinique, and St Vincent airports.

12 under-the-radar destinations in America's Midwest

Flyover Country, no more! The [Midwestern United States](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/articles/first-time-guide-to-the-midwest) may not be as flashy as their high-profile East or West Coast counterparts, but they're packed with fun attractions and experiences – often at a [fraction of the price](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/articles/usa-on-a-budget) of their [headline-grabbing neighbors](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/articles/best-cities-usa).

Pack a bag and get ready for a warm welcome, stunning landscapes, exciting towns and cities, and a whole lot of fun. Here are 12 fantastic Midwest destinations you might want to consider for your next getaway in America’s Heartland.

1. Milwaukee, Wisconsin
-----------------------

**Best city for live music**

Are you ready to rock? Multi-faceted [Milwaukee](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/usa/wisconsin/milwaukee) is home to the world’s largest outdoor music festival. It also holds [88Nine Radio Milwaukee](https://radiomilwaukee.org/discover-music/studio-milwaukee) live studio sessions, a notable club scene and the historic [Pabst and Riverside Theaters](https://pabsttheater.org/).

[Summerfest](https://www.summerfest.com/) comes to town for two weeks each June and July, attracting 800,000 attendees. There are more than a dozen stages, 800 performers and big-name headliners spanning a gamut of genres.

 Advertisement 

Music of a different tune, the throaty roar of [Harley-Davidson](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/usa/wisconsin/milwaukee/attractions/harley-davidson-plant/a/poi-sig/1250087/1006590) motorcycles, is an iconic part of Milwaukee’s cultural soundtrack. Catch live musical performances during the Bike Nights summer concert series at the [Harley-Davidson Museum](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/usa/milwaukee/attractions/harley-davidson-museum/a/poi-sig/1101545/1006590).

![Image 24: Sky Glider over the midway at the Ohio State Fair in August 2024.](https://lp-cms-production.imgix.net/2025-04/shutterstock2452351865.jpg?auto=format,compress&q=72&fit=crop)

Busy food stands and funfair rides at the Ohio State Fair in Columbus. WoodysPhotos/Shutterstock

2. Columbus, Ohio
-----------------

**Best city for fashion and style**

[Ohio](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/usa/great-lakes/ohio)’s trendy capital city has emerged as a fashion hub in recent years thanks to cutting-edge design schools, flashy showcase events, chic boutiques and major retail headquarters. Fun fact: Columbus is home to more resident fashion designers (including several Project Runway contestants) than any other city in the United States except New York and Los Angeles.

Open-air [Easton Town Center](https://eastontowncenter.com/) is populated with high-end retailers, sophisticated restaurants and upscale entertainment venues and the eclectic [Short North Arts District](https://shortnorth.org/) has fun boutiques and vintage shops to browse.

![Image 25: Traverse City Cherry Stand.](https://lp-cms-production.imgix.net/2024-04/GettyImages-1367897530.jpg?auto=format,compress&q=72&fit=crop)

A stand selling the region's famed cherries in Traverse City. Getty Images

3. Traverse City, Michigan
--------------------------

**Best for sweet delights**

Traverse City’s bread-and-butter crop, sweet and tart cherries, pops up at farm stands across the Up North region through late summer. You can also find then in [Traverse City Whiskey Co.](http://www.tcwhiskey.com/) cocktails, [Grand Traverse Pie Company](https://gtpie.com/) slices of pie, and sweet and savory [Cherry Republic](https://www.cherryrepublic.com/pages/cherry-republic-in-traverse-city) products all year.

Acres of idyllic wineries and orchards dot the rolling hills of the Leelanau and Old Mission peninsulas, perfectly paired with the gorgeous Lake Michigan vistas from nearby [Sleeping Bear Dunes National Lakeshore](https://www.nps.gov/slbe/index.htm).

Summer is high season, but the region also boasts enviable skiing terrain, fat-tire bike trails and snowmobile routes, making it a great option for [a winter getaway](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/articles/best-offbeat-winter-destinations-usa).

![Image 26: Kansas, SEP 16 2023 - Interior view of a Texaco airplane in the Aviation Museum](https://lp-cms-production.imgix.net/2025-04/shutterstock2368564933.jpg?auto=format,compress&q=72&fit=crop)

A Texaco airplane at the Kansas Aviation Museum. Kit Leong/Shutterstock

4. Wichita, Kansas
------------------

**Best for aviation innovation**

Wichita boasts a proud aviation heritage, producing 35 percent of the world’s general aircraft and home to one of just two known airworthy B-29s left in the world. The [Kansas Aviation Museum](http://kansasaviationmuseum.org/) educates and entertains with B-47 and B-52 jet bombers on display, flight simulators and interactive exhibits. The [Wichita-Sedgwick County Historical Museum](http://www.wichitahistory.org/) offers a deep dive into the lives of local flight innovators.

Make a detour to nearby Benton for sustenance at [Stearman Airfield Field Bar & Grill](https://www.stearmanbarandgrill.com/) and enjoy Southern-style fare while private planes take off and land on a runway 20 yards away.

![Image 27: Image of Night lights in skate park near MLK bridge leading into nightlife downtown Fort Wayne aerial](https://lp-cms-production.imgix.net/2023-09/GettyImages-1567441217.jpg?auto=format,compress&q=72&fit=crop)

The Martin Luther King Jr. Memorial Bridge illuminated at night in Fort Wayne. Getty Images

5. Fort Wayne, Indiana
----------------------

**Best city for families with kids**

 Advertisement 

The [second-largest city in Indiana](https://www.visitfortwayne.com/) brims with year-round family fun. Housed in the historic former City Light and Power Plant, STEM-based [Science Central](https://www.sciencecentral.org/) features more than 200 interactive displays and touring exhibits for visitors of all ages to get their hands on.

The awe-inspiring [Fort Wayne Children’s Zoo](https://kidszoo.org/) wows with exotic animals enjoying recreated African, Indonesian rainforest and Australian habitats. Meanwhile, the expansive new [Promenade Park](https://www.visitfortwayne.com/promenadepark/) on the downtown riverfront boasts water activities, a tree canopy trail and an amphitheater for outdoor shows.

After researching your family tree at the [Allen County Public Library’s Genealogy Center](http://genealogycenter.org/), feast along the [Fall Apple Trail](https://www.visitfortwayne.com/appletrail/) (this is Johnny Appleseed territory, after all). Or treat yourself to gourmet truffles, caramels and creams at [DeBrand Fine Chocolates](https://www.debrand.com/) any time of the year.

6. Iowa City, Iowa
------------------

**Best city for a literary tour**

Bookworms, writers and literary types gravitate to Iowa’s original state capital, which was awarded a [UNESCO City of Literature](http://www.iowacityofliterature.org/) designation in 2008. The University of Iowa (go Hawkeyes!) has hosted the prestigious [Iowa Writers’ Workshop](https://writersworkshop.uiowa.edu/) residency program for over 80 years and has produced numerous award-winning authors.

You might spy the resulting tomes on the shelves at Prairie Lights Bookstore, famous for its author appearances, in-store readings and expansive inventory. Read about 49 different Iowa-connected writers with a leisurely self-guided tour of the ground-level bronze panels comprising the downtown [Literary Walk](http://www.iowacityofliterature.org/lit-walk/).

![Image 28: Casey Illinois known as the Big Things Small Town attraction destination displays a giant Mailbox that claimed the Guinness World Record title on October 20, 2015.](https://lp-cms-production.imgix.net/2025-04/shutterstock2350102829.jpg?auto=format,compress&q=72&fit=crop)

The world's largest mailbox in Casey, Illinois. RozenskiP/Shutterstock

7. Casey, Illinois
------------------

**Best town for quirky charm**

This tiny town just off I-70, halfway between [Indianapolis](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/usa/great-lakes/indianapolis) and [St Louis](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/usa/great-plains/st-louis), makes a big impression on pit-stoppers. Populated with a handful of [Guinness-certified “World’s Largest” items](https://www.bigthingssmalltown.com/world-s-largest)– wind chimes, a rocking chair, a (working) mailbox, knitting needles, wooden shoes, a pitchfork and a golf tee. Along with many other supersized features, including a pencil, a yardstick, a spinning top and an ear of corn, [Casey](https://www.bigthingssmalltown.com/) serves up a fantastic free-to-visit collection of photo ops. A local business owner devised the promotion to encourage visitors to pull off the highway and explore the town. Mission accomplished for this Midwest [vacation spot](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/articles/best-weekend-getaways-usa).

![Image 29: View of the Nelson-Atkins Museum of Art located in Kansas City, Missouri.](https://lp-cms-production.imgix.net/2025-04/Shutterstock1203239314.jpg?auto=format,compress&q=72&fit=crop)

The exterior of the Nelson-Atkins Museum of Art in Kansas City. EQRoy/Shutterstock

8. Kansas City, Missouri
------------------------

**Best city for museums**

Straddling the state line where Missouri meets Kansas, the [City of Fountains](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/usa/great-plains/kansas-city)commemorates history, art and culture with a diverse assembly of museums to discover.

A respected local landmark since the Great Depression, the [Nelson-Atkins Museum of Art](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/usa/kansas-city/attractions/nelson-atkins-museum-of-art/a/poi-sig/457415/361958) displays a comprehensive collection spanning over 34,000 pieces and 5000 years.

The [National WWI Museum and Memorial](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/usa/kansas-city/attractions/national-wwi-museum/a/poi-sig/1130814/361958) is a moving repository for personal objects, documents and stories of the brave American soldiers who fought in this global conflict. The [Negro Leagues Baseball Museum](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/usa/kansas-city/attractions/negro-leagues-baseball-museum/a/poi-sig/1132459/361958) offers a meaningful multimedia examination of the African-American baseball experience throughout the league’s lifespan from the Civil War era through 1960.

Newly renovated, the [Harry S. Truman Presidential Library and Museum](https://www.trumanlibrary.gov/) honors the life and legacy of the only American President to hail from Missouri.

![Image 30: John Quincy Adams statue in Rapid City, South Dakota.](https://lp-cms-production.imgix.net/2023-04/shutterstock_1200926899.jpg?auto=format,compress&q=72&fit=crop)

A statue of President John Quincy Adams in Rapid City, South Dakota. Pierre Jean Durieu/Shutterstock

9. Rapid City, South Dakota
---------------------------

**Best city for US history**

Rapid City is a launching pad for adventure both within and beyond. Mount Rushmore and Crazy Horse, two historic memorials, are less than an hour’s drive away. The [Badlands National Park](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/usa/great-plains/south-dakota/attractions/badlands-national-park/a/poi-sig/1567087/361967) is also only a 60-minute drive.

Affectionately known as the ‘City of Presidents’, the city includes 43 life-size bronze statues of past US presidents in the walkable downtown area. No visit is complete without a walk down [Art Alley](https://www.artalleyrc.com/), an ever-changing laneway filled with graffiti representing creative expression and freedom of speech.

[Custer State Park](https://gfp.sd.gov/parks/detail/custer-state-park/), the state’s largest park, is also only a 30-minute drive away. Known for its scenic drives, Needles Highway is a wildlife wonderland – up to 1400 bison roam freely here, so watch for the stoic creatures as you pass through.

During Indigenous People’s Day in the fall, you can glimpse one of the nation's most significant cultural celebrations, [the Black Hills Pow Wow](https://www.blackhillspowwow.com/schedule). Combined with an impressive local bar and restaurant scene, Rapid City is quickly becoming one of the “coolest” cities in the Midwest.

![Image 31: Family members enjoy summer fun at LOST CITY OF ATLANTIS water rides at Mt. Olympus Water and Theme Park.](https://lp-cms-production.imgix.net/2025-04/Shutterstock1974373964.jpg?auto=format,compress&q=72&fit=crop)

The Lost City of Atlantis ride at a water park in Wisconsin Dells. Aaron of L.A. Photography/Shutterstock

10. Wisconsin Dells, Wisconsin
------------------------------

**Best city for outdoor adventures**

Known as the “Waterpark Capital of the World,” Wisconsin Dells offers fun and adventure for kids and the young at heart. Visit [Noah’s Ark](https://www.noahsarkwaterpark.com/), the largest outdoor waterpark in the US, or [Kalahari Resorts and Convention](https://www.travelwisconsin.com/resorts-lodges/kalahari-resorts-conventions-199496) when the weather takes a turn. For those who want the best of both worlds, [The Wilderness Resort](https://www.wildernessresort.com/)offers the largest indoor-outdoor combination.

Sail through the air and see Wisconsin Dells from above at[Bigfoot Ziplining](https://www.bigfootzip.com/) or take to the water on a tour with[The Original Wisconsin Ducks](https://www.wisconsinducktours.com/)to get your adrenaline pumping. Less than a 30-minute drive outside town is [Devil’s Lake State Park](https://dnr.wisconsin.gov/topic/parks/devilslake), with 29 miles of breathtaking hiking and 6 miles of off-road biking trails.

After all that adventure-seeking, book a relaxed sunset cruise with [Dells Boat Tours](https://www.dellsboats.com/sunset-dinner-cruise/) or check into [Sundara Spa](https://www.sundaraspa.com/), a top-rated adult-only retreat that offers day passes. For maximum zen, don’t skip the purifying bath ritual.

![Image 32: The busy streets of downtown Mackinac Island Michigan](https://lp-cms-production.imgix.net/2025-03/shutterstock1435108517.jpg?auto=format,compress&q=72&fit=crop)

A busy street on Mackinac Island, Michigan. Michael Deemer/Shutterstock

11. Mackinac Island, Michigan
-----------------------------

**Best place to unplug from the world**

No cars? No problem. Mackinac Island is only accessible by ferry or plane, and vehicles are not allowed on the island itself. To get around, visitors can take a horse-drawn carriage, rent a bike from the [Mackinac Island Bike Shop](https://bikemackinac.com/), walk or go on horseback.

Nature enthusiasts will love [Mackinac Island State Park](https://www.michigan.org/property/mackinac-island-state-park), which covers 80% of the island. [Arch Rock](https://www.mackinacisland.org/activities/arch-rock/), the most famous rock formation on the island, promises breathtaking views of Lake Huron. After all that exploration on foot, visit one of the island's famous fudge shops to refuel. [Joann’s Fudge](https://www.joannsfudge.com/) has been churning out delicious sweets since 1969.

![Image 33: This is the cliff of Palisade Head in the Lake Superior North Shore area of Minnesota.](https://lp-cms-production.imgix.net/2025-04/Shutterstock302033804.jpg?auto=format,compress&q=72&fit=crop)

Palisade Head North Shore area of Minnesota. AMB-MD Photography/Shutterstock

12. North Shore, Minnesota
--------------------------

**Best place for fall colors**

If you want to [the landscape ignite](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/articles/best-fall-colors-us) from mid-to-late September, head a few hours north of the [Twin Cities](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/articles/the-best-day-trips-from-minneapolis) to the North Shore, the stretch between Duluth and Grand Portage. As the season progresses, check the [DNR’s Fall Color Finder](https://www.dnr.state.mn.us/fall_colors/index.html) for the best time to visit this region. Hike along the [Superior Hiking Trail](https://www.exploreminnesota.com/profile/superior-hiking-trail/1871), with over 300 miles of footpaths and 50 trailheads. The 2.3-mile Oberg Mountain and 6.6-mile Bean and Bear Loop are two of the most popular hikes in the area.

For a unique experience, those on a budget can camp along one of the 94 backcountry campsites – make a reservation at one of the seven state parks along that stretch. If you'd prefer a little more luxury after a day's hiking, check out [Grand Superior Lodge](https://odysseyresorts.com/grand-superior/), [Bluefin Bay](https://www.bluefinbay.com/) or [Chateau LeVeaux](https://www.chateauleveaux.com/) for stunning views of Lake Superior.
